Answer: Richard Feynman‚Äôs 1959 article ‚Äî ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs Plenty of Room at the Bottom‚Äùhttps://web.pa.msu.edu/people/yang/RFeynman_plentySpace.pdfGordon Moore‚Äôs 1965 article ‚Äî‚ÄùCramming more Components into Integrated Circuits‚Äùgordon_moore_1965_article.pdfTracking Moore‚Äôs Law ProgressThe number of transistors from 1971 through to 2018 is doubling every two years.Kurzweil extended Moore‚Äôs law to a period of time before the development of the integrated circuit. There were four epochs. Mechanical from 1900 through to 1940. Electromechanical from 1940 to 1945. Vacuum tube from 1945 to 1960. Transistor from 1960 tRichard Feynman‚Äôs 1959 article ‚Äî ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs Plenty of Room at the Bottom‚Äùhttps://web.pa.msu.edu/people/yang/RFeynman_plentySpace.pdfGordon Moore‚Äôs 1965 article ‚Äî‚ÄùCramming more Components into Integrated Circuits‚Äùgordon_moore_1965_article.pdfTracking Moore‚Äôs Law ProgressThe number of transistors from 1971 through to 2018 is doubling every two years.Kurzweil extended Moore‚Äôs law to a period of time before the development of the integrated circuit. There were four epochs. Mechanical from 1900 through to 1940. Electromechanical from 1940 to 1945. Vacuum tube from 1945 to 1960. Transistor from 1960 through to 1971. Then our present epoch. Kurzweil noted an acceleration of the exponential with the introduction of solid state devices. This suggests a hyperbolic rather than an exponential growth. So, things are speeding up not slowing down.Doubtless future developments will proceed to new forms as they become available and we reach the limits of planar integrated circuits. These new platforms will include;These are not mutually exclusive and there are synergies connecting them together.Alan Turing developed a conceptual machine that carried out a program or algorithm and this is the basis of all computing in a mathematical sense.Here‚Äôs a totally mechanical version that is built in wood that could have been built any time since Turing devised the concept.Here data is stored by sliding a peg back and forth in a link that forms a chain which forms the tape. The peg is read mechanically as well, since the peg closes a linkage that engages a gear train that carries out the ‚Äòtruth table‚Äô within the machine. Programs are written by positioning the pegs in the chain link tape and running them through the processor and then read off the answer by looking at the pattern of pegs after running the program.Here is a kinesin molecule that ‚Äòwalks‚Äô along a microtuble carrying a vesicle.Here is how DNA replicates and expresses proteins. This shows how Helicase and other molecules process DNA to reproduce it and use it to make proteins.The similarity of these processes to Turing machinery described in 1936 has not been lost on some biologists and computer scientists. Can we make molecular scale computing systems?Many scientists say yes!A mechanical Turing machine: blueprint for a biomolecular computerCarbon Nanotubes have been considered in a variety of roleshttps://www.researchgate.net/publication/264097838_A_Study_on_Nano-Accelerometer_based_on_Carbon_NanotubeCarbon nanotube transistors make the leap from lab to factory floorCarbon nanotube transistors make the leap from lab to factory floorSteering Carbon Nanotubes to Scavenger Receptor Recognition by Nanotube Surface Chemistry Modification Partially Alleviates NFŒ∫B Activation and Reduces Its ImmunotoxicityCarbon Nanotubes marked with molecules that bind to the nanotube have the capacity to store an incredible amount of information. Molecules that move along the nanotube and shift the molecules around in response to their position have the capacity to read and write information and implement a Turing machine at the molecular scale.Armchair single-walled nanotubeZig-Zag single-walled nanotube (note each hexagon rotates 60 degrees around the tube. These are not the only configurations. Slice open the tube and lay it flat forming a monomolecular layer of graphene and the strip may be oriented any number of ways.The narrowest zig zag type is 738 picometers in circumference and 234.9 picometers in diameter. Spacing along the edges is 142 picometers. There are six positions that a molecule attached to the surface may take during each rotation.Three molecules shifted one position left or right stores 3 bits of information per rotation. Coded as three units in a group stores 8 bits of information 000 to 111 stores one byte per molecular length of the nanotube. Changing the chirality changes the length of this to 6 bits which permit hexadecimal storage with a check bit.Using the simplest approach a total of 14.2 gigabytes per meter. 1 km of this tube is 283.56 picograms. That‚Äôs 4*10^26 bits/kg.A 12.89 km long tube containing 182.95 trillion bytes of information is wrapped into a spherical shell 23 microns in diameter forming 2985 layers 1 micron thick and massing 3.655 nanograms.Helicase type molecules encase the strand and operate like Turing read write heads which move nitrogen molecules between two locations on the carbon nanotube surface to encode information. The helicase molecules process a billion locations per second and several operate along the length of each molecule. A Motorola 64k IC has been reduced to a 128,000 byte Turing tape which operates UNIX, using byte pairs to encode information along the nanotube.https://www.researchgate.net/publication/231713010_Capillary_Phase_Transitions_of_n-Alkanes_in_a_Carbon_Nanotubehttp://www.sci-news.com/othersciences/chemistry/carbyne-ultra-long-1d-carbon-chains-03770.htmlA one dimensional carbyne molecule passes through the center and responds to the helicase type kinesin molecule providing power to the unit. Every 128,000 intervals the single walled nanotube is stitched together with a multi-walled nanotube. This multi-walled nanotube is equipped with acceleration sensors, light sensors, light emitters, photovoltaic molecules and various receptor molecules for water vapour and carbon dioxide specifically.These multiwalled tubes provide power to the computing strands and the computing strands control the behaviour of the connecting tubes. In this way the tube grows flexes and performs a variety of functions. The coil collects CO2 at the receptor and separates the molecule with solar power, and transports carbon gathered in this way to the end of the tube extending it. When the foglet shell is 2 microns thick the shell splits in two hemispherical shell halves, and the broken ends of the extended spiral anneal to the broken ends of the original spiral and the new spiral flexes outward creating a copy of the original sphere.When not reproducing the shell grows 12 arms equally spaced, each of these arms has the same computing and operational setup as the sphere.Information and energy is sent along the length of the tube. A single 23 micron diameter shell contains 1 billion processors each running UNIX at 1 billion introductions per second and each as capable of a PDP 11/70 of the 1970s!! These are the heart of each self replicating foglet. Trillions of foglets operate together to form smart matter that self assemble into anything desired.One of the world's smallest electronic circuits created15 nanometer structures 3.45 trillion bits per gram. 4.10*10^23 bits per gram of the molecular device above isln(4.10*10^23/(3.45*10^12))/ln(2) = 36.79 doublings 73.58 years ~2094 ADAssuming exponential growth. However, as mentioned previously growth in capacity is hyperbolic tending toward infinity in the 2035 to 2040 time frame.I can see this with modern personal supercomputers. I model all these chemical things at the molecular level and use atomic force microscopes to pattern the graphene into strips and deposit other molecules on to those strips and cause them to fold up in highly controlled ways. Once functioning foglets are operational they may be programmed to carry out very sophisticated operations improving functionality very quickly

Answer: Moore‚Äôs Law is directly about circuit density or cost, not processing power (though processing power is certainly an outcome of doubling circuits (logic gates) over time). Prior to integrated circuits (which Moore‚Äôs Law describes, but I suspect it is a case of Wright‚Äôs Law) there were mechanical switches, vacuum tubes, and transistors. Each of the prior technologies got faster/cheaper/better for a duration of time, then was replaced. I expect the same is true of Moore‚Äôs Law. There are several technologies that together or individually may form the replacement for Moore‚Äôs Law including optical/Moore‚Äôs Law is directly about circuit density or cost, not processing power (though processing power is certainly an outcome of doubling circuits (logic gates) over time). Prior to integrated circuits (which Moore‚Äôs Law describes, but I suspect it is a case of Wright‚Äôs Law) there were mechanical switches, vacuum tubes, and transistors. Each of the prior technologies got faster/cheaper/better for a duration of time, then was replaced. I expect the same is true of Moore‚Äôs Law. There are several technologies that together or individually may form the replacement for Moore‚Äôs Law including optical/photonic computing, quantum computing, carbon nanotube chips, 3D computing (integrated chips are flat or 2.5D-stacked).I suspect we ‚Äúain‚Äôt seen nothing yet‚Äù for human innovation as we‚Äôll be leveraging VR, brain-computer interfaces, and AI for future work.

Answer: I see no evidence that innovation is slowing. Moore‚Äôs law is an observation about how the semiconductor industry was progressing. It is now progressing in a different way. Take a look at Apple‚Äôs M1 chip and tell me that the innovation is not continuing in the semiconductor world. Other technology moves at a different rate. Look at a 1950 Ford and a 2020 Tesla and tell me that innovation isn‚Äôt occurring in the auto industry. Battery technology is slower than we want it to be. Converting water to hydrogen is still too expensive. Add other industries and take a look. Mostly innovation is occurrinI see no evidence that innovation is slowing. Moore‚Äôs law is an observation about how the semiconductor industry was progressing. It is now progressing in a different way. Take a look at Apple‚Äôs M1 chip and tell me that the innovation is not continuing in the semiconductor world. Other technology moves at a different rate. Look at a 1950 Ford and a 2020 Tesla and tell me that innovation isn‚Äôt occurring in the auto industry. Battery technology is slower than we want it to be. Converting water to hydrogen is still too expensive. Add other industries and take a look. Mostly innovation is occurring but not at the rate we hope for. And the gimmicks sell, so why not make some money on the way?
